Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of a wall on crime rates in El Paso, stating that it went from being one of the most dangerous cities in the country to one of the safest cities overnight.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that El Paso has historically been a relatively safe city with low crime rates compared to other big cities in Texas and the national average.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that the wall was solely responsible for the decrease in crime rates in El Paso.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the construction of a wall was the primary factor in reducing crime rates in El Paso, ignoring other factors such as increased border patrol agents and existing low crime rates.
Exist alternative explanation: There are alternative explanations for the decrease in crime rates in El Paso, such as the presence of border patrol agents and other law enforcement efforts, rather than solely attributing it to the construction of a wall.
